content.description:
Climb the abyss. In general, if the climbing in the slot is hard or annoying, climb the wonderfully featured, orange face on either side.

P1: Climb the abyss; maybe wet your pants here. Step right to orange rock on the arete, either immediately on entering the abyss or below the bush. Above the bush, continue up, either in the crack/corner or on the orange face to the right. Final moves in the corner gain a stance on scalloped rock below the grey, double roofs. (160’)

P2, right option: Escape the belay via traversing out right at the roof’s right end; continue 25’ to the finger/thin hands crack that leads up and back left. Belay at a spacious stance below the next roof; the belay takes a #5 and #6 camalot (other gear options can be contrived). (60’)

P2, direct option: Climb the roof directly; #4/#5 camalots can be employed. Belay at a spacious stance below the next roof; the belay takes a #5 and #6 camalot (other gear options can be contrived). (40’)

P3, right option: Climb around the roof on good holds to its left; then head up and right, following the orange rock to the left of the abyss. Belay on spacious stance below a grey headwall on the right side of the abyss. (200’) P4, right option: Continue easily to the top.

P3, left option: Climb around the roof on good holds to its left; continue traversing left about 50’ until the angle above eases and continue up to a spacious ledge below a stripe/buttress of super-quality, orange rock. (100’) P4, left option: Up the orange stripe; at its top, angle up and right. The difficulty eases; scamper up and a little right to the summit.
content.protection: Normal rack. Add gear to 4”-5” for direct roof variation
content.location: The all-too-obvious sundering of the center of the formation that leads directly to the top; it starts at the wide crack just above the clump of trees close to the base of the cliff.

content.description:
Perhaps you are avoiding off-widths because of a subliminal fear of being placed in a grave while still alive? If so, this climb is for you…

Climb the crack system for 220’

300’ of scrambling will lead to the sand/talus/slabs that will bring you back to the start; best to descend left/west to return to the base.
content.protection: Gear to #6 camalot; extras in the 1-3” range if you like extras
content.location: Start on a ledge in an alcove at the base of the all too obvious, wide crack system that spits the cliff at its northwest end. Access via traverse in from the (climber’s) left.

content.description: P1: Climb featured rock up and right, aiming for a 20’ overhanging crack in an obtuse corner. Struggle up the overhanging crack, crux. Belay on the ample ledge system at its top. (200’) P2: Climb the crack system on the face at the left end of the belay ledge. Up the face, eventually joining with The Astraphobia Treatment. (200’) P3: Pick a way through the last steep section and scramble easily to the summit. (100’)
content.location:
Start 20 feet left of

The Astraphobia Treatment

.

content.description:
P1: Up the wide crack; belay at good stance on the right at its top.

P2: Face climb up and back left to the arete, fiddly gear; up the arete past a car sized boulder; then head up and right, aiming for an obvious, vertical crack in the final headwall; belay at its base.

P3: Up the crack; continue to the summit when the difficulty eases.
content.location: The obvious crack right of Taphophobia, which can be accessed either by traversing/down-climbing in from the left or climbing an easy pitch from below.

content.description:
An alternate start to

The Astraphobia Treatment

. The climbing is exceptional but for the detached flake that comprises the right side of the landmark roof 80’ up.

Head toward the obvious roof about 80’ up; best not to touch the roof’s right side. Another 60’ of easier climbing puts you at the top of the first pitch of

The Astraphobia Treatment.
content.location: Start about 80 feet right of the start of The Astraphobia Treatment, just left of a buttress/left facing corner/gulley and just right of a smaller, right facing corner.

content.description:
We think this climb is better than

Holdless Horror

or

Bulldozier

, Tuolumne Meadows climbs of similar difficulty and length. That said, the climbing is of a different character—more alpine and the feldspar crystal knobs of Dozier Dome are replaced by high quality, orange-patinated, fine-grained granitic features.

P1 Climb the crack/chimney system to a (the 2nd) ledge system that offers branching left. 170’.

P2 & P3. 300 more feet to the summit. For rope drag purposes, probably best to continue up the right angling crack system that is now hand-crack sized; continue as the crack heads up and right across the south face and into a short trough behind a triangular pinnacle; belay at/near the far end of the trough; 100’. Then up the south face/southeast arete to the summit; 200’

From the top, follow the ridge (exposed 2nd class) 400’ until it is possible to descend sand/talus/slabs back to the base, either to the east or the west.
content.protection: gear to #6 camalot; extras in the 1-3” range if you like extras
content.location: At the right side of the south face, start at the base of the wide crack system that slants up and right, ending at a triangular pinnacle.
